newsitem.title: USA: US CORPORATE BONDS - Junk bonds quiet but steady.
newsitem.headline: US CORPORATE BONDS - Junk bonds quiet but steady.

text.p: U.S. high-yield corporate bonds were little changed in a typically quiet summer Friday session, while some big investment grade issuers capitalized on lower rates, dealers said.

High-yield issuance was limited to Archibald Candy Corp's $100 million 10.25 percent B2/single-B seven-year senior secured note deal, priced at par to yield 385 basis points over U.S. Treasuries via Jefferies & Co.
The issue was well bid in the aftermarket, traders said, quoted at 101-1/4 at mid-afternoon.

Despite the apparent success of that deal, several traders said the market was extremely quiet on Friday and a true read of investor sentiment was difficult to gauge. But opinions were mixed, as were prices, regarding any recovery of the tone from the sloppy session endured on Thursday.
"There are a few spotty things happening with some things up and some down," one trader at a New York shop said. "But there's a lot of apathy today and on the whole things are unchanged."

Closely watched high-yield bond fund cash flows from AMG Data provided little solace on Friday. Weekly inflows slowed to $128.3 million in the week ended June 25, compared to $457.7 million and $627.4 million in the prior two weeks.

Some issues slated for pricing on Friday were yet to be seen by late afternoon. Among the issues are: Boyd Gaming Corp's $250 million 10-year 144a senior subordinated notes from Salomon Brothers; Glasstech Inc's $70 million 10-year 144a senior notes from CIBC Wood Gundy Securities; and West Coast Entertainment Corp's $110 million 144a seven-year senior notes from Credit Suisse First Boston.
Salomon Brothers and CIBC Wood Gundy did not return phone calls late in the session. West Coast Entertainment's pricing timeframe was still uncertain at that time, said a source close to that deal.
Secondary high-yield trades were limited. Grand Union's 12 percent debt due 2004 dropped about one point, but one trader discounted the weakness as all trades were small.

In the investment grade arena, Bear Stearns Cos Inc sold $400 million 6-1/2 percent three-year notes to yield 40 basis points over Treasuries and First Maryland Bancorp issued $200 million 7.20 percent 10-year notes to yield 76 basis points over the curve.
Bear Stearns & Co led the former deal and Goldman Sachs & Co managed the latter.
Investment grade issuance totaled about $7.5 billion on the week. Junk bond supply was more than $2.5 billion.

In the Treasury market, a Federal Reserve coupon pass and short-covering helped break prices out of a week-long slump, analysts there said. The benchmark 30-year bond closed up 14/32 to yield 6.78 percent and the 10-year T-note rose 8/32 to yield 6.46 percent.
